post_info.post_title: I wonder where they got their weapons!!

Somewhere in Syria? emoticon_confused

 
 I would say they passed through Syria, but came from Iraq. Of course I can't prove it because I didn't actually witness the line of possession.

I would say they passed through Syria, but came from Iraq. Of course I can't prove it because I didn't actually witness the line of possession.

 
 But Iraq didn`t have any chemical weapons... how could they have come from there ;)

emoticon_xhoho 
But Iraq didn`t have any chemical weapons... how could they have come from there ;)
 emoticon_xhoho emoticon_xhoho emoticon_xhoho emoticon_xhoho

According to the first news link n the list, http://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/ap/20040427/ap_on_re_mi_ea/jordan_terror_suspects_6
 
 They bought 20 tons of raw chemicals
 
 
Al-Jayousi said he received about $170,000 from al-Zarqawi to finance the plot and used part of it to buy 20 tons of chemicals. 
 
 
 which they were apparently combining ontheir own in a laboratory
 
 
Al-Jayousi said he began making the explosives in a laboratory in Irbid, 55 miles north of Amman. Later he moved the explosives to locations in at least two nearby towns. 
 
 
 ANd they apparently made their own chemical weapons as well
 
 
Citing unidentified technical experts, the commentator said the suspects had made enough explosives to cause "two explosions — conventional and chemical — which were to have directly affected an area within a one-mile radius." 
 
 
 In other words, the chemical weapons did not come from Syria, and ceratianly did not come from Iraq. They were home brewed. Look into chemical weapons. Most of them could be made in your basement fairly simply.

In other words, the chemical weapons did not come from Syria, and ceratianly did not come from Iraq. They were home brewed. Look into chemical weapons. Most of them could be made in your basement fairly simply.

 
 As "they" came from Syria with three trucks filled with explosives, wouldn`t that imply that their homebrewed chemicals came from Syria as well? (unless they made their chemicals in another country and took a detour through Syria for some odd reason) ;)

That may be. Though it appears the vehicles actually came from jordan
 
 "Syria has denied the claims. In the videotape, however, the militants said they acquired the vehicles in Jordan. "
 
 
 Regardless, the chemicals they were using were most likely nothing special. You can make VX from supplies you geta t a grocery store, an auto parts store, and a hardware store. Mc Veigh blew up the OK city federal building with fertilizer. Odds are, none of the chemicals they were using were anything restricted (I am not sure that, besides radiological agents, any raw chemicals are really restricted, though some are a litttle hard to find). 
 
 I was just pointing out that trying to link these guys to Saddams imaginary WMDs requires a pretty severe leap of blind faith.

Looking at the second article on that list, http://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/afp/20040427/wl_mideast_afp/jordan_attacks_qaeda_040427113653
 
 
IT appears that the chemicals were obtained locally, and were mostly off the shelf type stuff.
 
 But officials did not provide details on those last two targets nor specify the type of chemicals they said the suspects behind bars had bought on the local market
 
 A source close to the investigation told AFP the chemicals consisted of "70 chemical agents, some of which were pesticides, which mixed together could have produced a formidable chemical weapon never used before". 
 
 
 
 It also appears that syria was in the dark about the whole thing.
 
 
However, the Jordanian authorities have said they do not believe the Syrian government was aware of what was going on.

@ Daewo
 
 Yeah, I was just goofing around. I understood your point, I was just trying to salvage my credability and didn`t mean to imply that Syria as a country had anything to do with it.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  I wonder where they got their weapons!!
